But I couldn't give up now.
But this wasn't the time for self-pity.
But there was no backing out now.
But I had to see this through.
But I was in too deep.
But I couldn't take the easy way out.
But this was my mess. I had to clean it up.
But too many questions were still unanswered.
But there was too much at stake.
But I had to keep going.
But I knew there was no walking away.
But this wasn't just about me.
But I had no choice but to push on.
Fate was mocking me, the same bad joke I'd heard a hundred times before.
The setting had changed, but the rest was all too familiar.
I couldn't remember the last time I'd felt anything but regret.
All those failures I'd banked had been gathering interest.
It had been so long since I'd seen a good idea, I'd forgotten what they looked like.
This was the longest suicide attempt in history.
In their faces I saw myself, the ghost of my mistakes.
No amount of pills could numb this much pain.
Every gunshot echoed in the past.
I'd filled my body with so much poison it was all I could taste.
People kept telling me I was going to hell. Seemed I'd arrived early.
Guilt had ambushed me once again. I never saw her coming.
It felt like I was running blind, chasing the skyline.
My world was fading around me, turning everything to black.
I wasn't the man I used to be, and even he wasn't up to much.
Here I was again, waging a war that wasn't mine for reasons I didn't fully understand.
Once again I'd confused remorse with purpose.
Things had a way of turning out right for all the wrong people.
All I was doing was making a bad situation worse.
I was a problem trying to be a solution.
I was trying to put on an act when the curtain was already down.
All I had left was emptiness, and that had rarely served me well.
There was no saving anyone, least of all me.
I was back on the same path, and I knew where it led.
I was so far behind the pace, I was running a different race.
Reality was about to come crashing down.
This was my sentence. To keep making same mistakes.
It felt like every step was taking me further away from the truth.

~z~I felt sick and my vision swam... I was fading fast.
~z~The small injuries took their toll right about then... if I didn't patch up, I'd soon be checking out.
~z~The odds of me surviving suddenly shortened... I was bleeding, bad.
~z~As soon as the fight ended, I'd have to patch myself up.
~z~That's when I more or less stopped in my tracks... I was in a world of pain.
~z~My health was my own to abuse... I guess I didn't appreciate strangers helping.
~z~A couple more shots and I'd know the face of the man that killed me.
~z~There's only so much abuse a body can take... especially one as old and beat up as mine.
~z~This wasn't the time to be exploring.
~z~There was still work to be done.
~z~I still had other problems to deal with.
~z~I was jumping the gun with bullets left to shoot.
~z~I had to finish what I'd started.
~z~I was wishing my enemies away, but they were very much alive.
~z~I had to deal with the immediate problem first.
~z~I was letting myself get distracted from the task at hand.
~z~They were still out there, waiting to put a bullet in me.
~z~That would have to wait. I had more pressing concerns.
~z~I was getting my priorities out of whack.
~z~There was no avoiding it; I had to clean house.
~z~I couldn't turn my back on them for a second.
~z~I couldn't ignore the guys out to kill me.
~z~A short lapse in concentration would have gotten me killed.
~z~I needed to neutralise the bad guys first.
~z~There were still guys who wanted me dead.
~z~I couldn't just pretend my "friends" weren't there.
~z~I had to deal with them. I couldn't just put my head in the sand.
~z~If I turned my back, I'd get a bullet in it.
~z~There'll be time for that in a minute.
~z~Fucking around would have gotten me killed.
~z~Finding ammo took me back into my comfort zone.
~z~So I guess there was a divine force, giving bullets to the needy.
~z~It was a good time to find more ammo.
~z~I took the ammo - I'm sure the previous owner didn't mind.
~z~I found some ammo - just in time.
~z~One of life's small victories - more ammo.
~z~Ammo restock, and not a second too soon.
~z~More ammo to keep me going. Good.
~z~Right about then, I decided to change weapons.
~z~The grip was still warm from the dead man's grasp.
~z~I improvised, and picked up the weapon of a dead man.
~z~I guess the previous owner was finished with the weapon.
~z~I did my bit for the planet, and recycled a gun.
~z~I picked up the gun - time to turn their weapons against them.
~z~I didn't hesitate when I spotted the exact weapon I was looking for.
~z~Pills - I didn't like to leave home without them.
~z~Pain killers: A small beacon in a world of hurt.
~z~Pain killers were one of the only things that made me feel good about myself lately.
~z~Pills - Always good to see an old friend.
~z~I took the pills, I'm sure they wouldn't be missed.
~z~My need was greater than pretty much everyone's; so I grabbed the pain killers.
~z~I found some pain killers - my favorite brand, too.
~z~I'd be a dead man, if I didn't act fast.
~z~My body kept soaking up its punishment - with a certain amount of protest.
~z~I needed to find some time to take a pain killer.
~z~I felt something give inside when the last bullet hit.
~z~I decided now might be a good time to rest up and self-medicate, like a good American.
~z~Right after this fight, I promised myself a breather to patch up.
~z~If I didn't stop and patch up soon, there was a distinct possibility I might stop for good.
~z~I was beat up pretty bad, but the rattle of pills in my pocket reassured me.
~z~I was getting through my ammo fast.
~z~A few more shots and I'd be out of ammo.
~z~I had a few shots left; I'd have to make them count.
~z~I knew I had to get some ammo, or switch guns soon.
~z~I was running low on ammo - guns seem pretty deadly when I run out of ammo.
~z~If I ran out of ammo now - I'd have to go to plan B. Whatever that was.
~z~In a few shots' time, I'd be firing blanks.
~z~Soon this gun would be little more than a kid's toy unless I found some ammo.
~z~It was right about then I noticed I'd almost run out of ammo.
~z~My body was telling me to stop - I could shut it up if I found some pills.
~z~I was in bad shape. Pain killers were the only solution I knew, but I had none.
~z~I'd taken a telling wound... Finding pills became a priority.
~z~I'd taken a beating... but I was out of pain killers.
~z~The damage was taking its toll... great time to be out of pain killers.
~z~I was out of pain killers, but at least I was alive.
~z~The pain throbbed throughout my body - and I had nothing to dull it.
~z~Every move I took sent pain shooting through my body - I had to find some pain killers.
~z~I was like someone without health insurance, sick, and in need of meds.
~z~I swallowed a handful of pills and waited for them to do their magic.
~z~The pills took the edge off the pain...
~z~The only reason I ever read the instructions on those things, is so that I could ignore them.
~z~I took something to make me feel better about myself.
~z~Pain killers - a short term solution, but I rarely look further than that, these days.
~z~I knew too many pills would screw me up, but I guess I was kinda screwed already.
~z~Just a couple of pills to chase away the aches and pains, and the thoughts and feelings.
~z~I took something to keep me going, but I knew this was a debt I'd have to pay.
~z~Killing the fucker that plugged me pulled me back from the brink. Now I was pissed.
~z~I'll always wonder what went through that guy's head... he thought I was finished. Soon enough, he was.
~z~Surprise time, my friend! Next time make sure I STAY down.
~z~It took all the strength I had left to squeeze the trigger. When I saw the guy drop, I knew I wasn't finished, yet.
~z~There's nothing quite as motivating as the smug look of a chump that thinks he's killed you.
~z~I felt like I'd clawed my way out of a wooden box in a six foot hole - that was too close.
~z~I thought I was gone. I'm not sure how I felt about that. But it was good to be back.
~z~Had nobody told them? You can't kill a dead man.
~z~I guess I wasn't ready to be staring at the roof of some memorial home just yet.
~z~They didn't want the bombs to go off.
~z~Suddenly a lot of bad workmen were blaming their tools.
~z~They had to cut out the rot.
~z~The higher ups wanted the bombs set. They didn't care how many lives it cost.
~z~There was one name on all the bullets.
~z~They had a name on their list, and they'd strike it off no matter what.
~z~They were rattled, confused, turning on each other.
~z~All of a sudden, the enemy seemed revived.
~z~They thought if they could stay in control a while longer, relief might come.
~z~They wanted it, they were going to take it.
~z~Their mistakes had blown up in their face.
~z~They weren't in the mood for sharing.
~z~They knew where they were going, and they knew what they had to do.
~z~The rats were back in their holes.
~z~Panic had set in - everyone had become a target.
~z~Now their weapons had turned on them too.
~z~Their whole operation was about to go up in smoke.
~z~The message had been delivered loud and clear.
~z~It only takes one bad decision for friend to become foe.
~z~They wouldn't stop until the target was dead, or they were.
~z~It was head on, man to man, a fight to the death.
~z~The hate they drew was a sick sort of compliment.
~z~They'd been given front seats to the firework show.
~z~Sometimes even the smallest stake seems like it's worth fighting for.
~z~They didn't care if they lived, as long as the bombs weren't set.
~z~Both sides were about to suffer considerable casualties.
~z~They were all after the same scalp.
~z~Some things don't turn out how they're planned.
~z~They had their explosives. All they needed was to run the gauntlet and fit them.
~z~They wouldn't let anyone slow them down.
~z~These kids had one thing on their mind.
~z~They'd defuse the bombs at any cost.
~z~Far as they were concerned, no one was going to push them off this patch.
~z~Issued with explosives, they were sent to their death.
~z~Time was definitely not on their side.
~z~It would be a fight for every inch.
~z~It was time to toast the guest of honour.
~z~Occupation was the name of the game.
~z~They were getting careless, revealing their positions.
~z~Each bullet they'd banked was getting paid back with interest.
~z~Every enemy that came after them made them stronger.
~z~It was time to get down to business.
~z~Gang allegiances were the only thing that would keep them alive.
~z~Moments like these, it's best to trust no one.
~z~Some were singled out from the rest.
~z~They had to collect the package and deliver it.
~z~They did what they said they would.
~z~Their resources were depleted, but they still had a chance.
~z~Words will only take you so far.
~z~If they wanted them, they would have to come and get them.
~z~They all knew what they were after.
~z~They weren't messing around. One shot, one kill.
~z~It was time to cash that check.
~z~The lambs were coming to the slaughter.
~z~They were coming, and they were coming quick.
~z~No one held the throne for long. They just wanted a chance to sit on it.
~z~What do they say? Make hay while the sun shines.
~z~I pity the bagmen they sent out on those days.
~z~The next day, some mothers would weep.
~z~Only a group of angry psychopaths stood between them and where they had to go.
~z~The bomb squad had been called in.
~z~They weren't going to give it up easy.
~z~Every bullet was being made to work twice as hard.
~z~It was clear who had the staying power.
~z~They had their sights on a new goal.
~z~There was no glory to be found in this blaze.
~z~There were packages to collect and drop off, people to kill. Business.
~z~This was their patch, and they were going to fight for it.
~z~Clumsily put together bombs in hand, they headed for their targets.
~z~They'd done enough waiting. They wanted them dead.
~z~They say it only takes one rotten apple.
~z~There was one name on everyone's lips.
~z~They had a name to cross off their list.
~z~They'd played with fire; now they were getting burned.
~z~These guys were going to fight for what was theirs.
~z~There was a malfunction in the hardware.
~z~Possession is nine tenths of the law.
~z~The runners were sent out without much regard for whether they'd come back.
~z~Suddenly they weren't going down as easy.
~z~The place wasn't going to blow on their watch.
~z~Someone had a cross on their back,
~z~It was time to remove the thorn from their side.
~z~Some bullets you ain't never getting up from.
~z~Even the smallest foothold was worth keeping.
~z~The target was picked and the bombs were in hand.
~z~It'd be a walk in the park. If that park was filled with guys who wanted you dead.
~z~Sometimes you learn the hard way who your friends are.
~z~It was their turn to sit at the high table.
~z~Why they didn't leave, I don't know. They wanted to stop the destruction.
~z~They'd got two eyes for the price of one.
~z~Being a courier isn't as easy as it sounds.
~z~If they could prevent the explosions, they'd be heroes for a day.
~z~It had come to its unnatural conclusion.
~z~They had someone special to think about.
~z~Being on the wrong side was going to get you killed.
~z~You can't kill an enemy you can't see.
~z~There was always time for more killing.
~z~Not everyone was coming home that night.
~z~One of them was getting all the attention.
~z~Seemed as if they couldn't reload fast enough.
~z~A smarter bunch might have scaled back their ambitions.
~z~There was some grim satisfaction in the act.
~z~They seemed to be getting tougher rather than weaker.
~z~They went at each other one last time.
~z~They were keeping their enemies way too close.
~z~No one told them where they could go.
~z~One poor fool was taking all the blame.
~z~They would hold their ground or be buried in it.
~z~There was someone baying for their blood.
~z~No one would take out their people.
~z~They'd take it and hold it as long as they could.
~z~They were playing clever, making them show their cards too early.
~z~It was a simple game of plant and detonate.
~z~They knew they were coming. They knew what to do about it.
~z~They'd gotten two eyes for the price of one.
~z~It would be a mad, scrappy fight for survival.
~z~They were a family. And they'd fight to protect it.
~z~Now time had turned against them as well.
~z~They were coming back even stronger than before.
~z~Like a drunk with his bottle, they were going to hold onto it.
~z~From their cold dead hands, they might have said.
~z~Their second wind was like a hurricane.
~z~They had their eye on the prize.
~z~They'd become sluggish, slow on the draw.
~z~They had the equipment, and the plan, they just had to execute it.
~z~There was a wolf in sheep's clothing.
~z~They stopped caring who they were shooting at.
~z~If they had their say, no one was moving through there.
~z~The stuff was right in front of them.
~z~They were spread pretty thin, but they didn't back down.
~z~This was a bad time to be behind the pace.
~z~There was a grisly toll to be paid on this road.
~z~If they could push them out for a few short hours, that might be enough.
~z~If the attention bothered them, they didn't show it.
~z~Nobody got to leave the party early.
~z~No one was going to kill their people.
~z~It was a humble scrap, but it was all they had.
~z~Suddenly every move they made was too slow.
~z~It was going to be a massacre.
~z~Dispossession was the order of the day.
~z~You don't like the game, you change the rules.
~z~The added attention was the price they paid for their skill.
~z~What had been started was gonna get finished.
~z~It was best not to think about what lay ahead of them.
~z~They were bringing out the big guns.
~z~The heat was about to get hotter.
~z~Seemed they were done playing with the kids' toys.
~z~All of a sudden, the odds were less even.

~z~Here I was, about to execute this poor bastard like some dime store angel of death
~z~I wouldn't know right from wrong if one of them was helping the poor and the other was banging my sister.
~z~These were Becker's guys. Him and Victor had a private airport to go with their private army, and their private jet.
~z~Sao Paulo's version of the TSA wanted to give me a rubdown, and I wasn't into those at the best of times.
~z~If you can get this army out our way!
~z~So much for pulling strings behind the scenes.
~z~We're too close! We need to finish this!
~z~The perfect end to a perfect holiday.
~z~Come on! We've got a flight to catch!
~z~It's not going to take off without us!
~z~I'm normally a behind the desk kind of cop.
~z~If only I'd been one of them, too.
~z~If he gets out of the country...
~z~They don't want us getting down this runway!
~z~Aye! We need to clear the runway!
~z~Of course they have their armored personnel vehicle!
~z~They behave like an army, and they're equipped like one!
~z~I don't know how much more we can take!
~z~Come on, Max, they're going to kill us!
~z~We need to get past these guys!
~z~I don't want to drive into the back of a bullet!
~z~You can't care much about citizen's rights if you're driving a tank!
~z~I don't get the sense that citizens rights are high on their agenda right now.
~z~These assholes really want to kill us.
~z~Look! A squad is coming in from the right!
~z~Guys are running in over on the right.
~z~Look! There's a whole team of them!
~z~Those cars aren't trying to make friends!
~z~Every one in those four by fours is on Branco's payroll.
~z~You see how far the corruption reaches!
~z~If I wasn't planning on packing myself in their suitcase, I'd have to get out into the terminal.
~z~It seemed the exit was on the next level.
~z~I guess I'm going to die in the dark.
~z~Turn the lights on. There's someone in here.
~z~A tram had just left. If I could get the power back up again, I'd be able to get to the next terminal.
~z~It didn't look like there would be any trams leaving until the power was on.
~z~By the looks of it, Becker wasn't taking any chances. Me? I was on a seriously long shot.
~z~The customer restroom led to the departure gates.
~z~There'd be a bunch of killers through there, and maybe Victor, too.
~z~The customer restroom. I could get through to the departure gates up ahead.
~z~I always liked to travel on medication.
~z~I meant to end this how I'd begun it - heavily medicated.
~z~I could deal with my remaining substance abuse issues when this was all over.
~z~Chances were I wasn't going to be alive much longer, so why not get a buzz on.
~z~The UFE had damaged the tram's auto controls - It wasn't stopping at the stations anymore.
~z~I was fighting for my life on an out of control train.
~z~Out manned, out gunned, and if past performance was anything to go by, out smarted too. It was time, once again, to rely on dumb luck.
~z~He ain't gone yet. Get me close!
~z~The catwalk might take me through the rest of the airport.
~z~Finally, it was time to catch that tram.
~z~I needed to press the button to trigger the divider.
~z~There was a button on the wall that would open up the next section of the airport.
~z~The doors lead in the direction of the main terminal.
~z~The tram to the next terminal was down the escalators.
~z~If I was going to be able to turn the power on anywhere, it'd be in the office.
~z~It looked like they'd cut the power off in the office at the end of the platform. That was where I'd get it running.
~z~They weren't going to wait for me to wave them goodbye.
~z~If I wanted to be part of the sending off party, I had to step it up.
~z~I had no reason to hang around by these gates. They weren't here, and the shops were closed.
~z~Keep going, Max. They're here somewhere. Find them!
~z~There weren't any other flights clogging up air traffic control.
~z~Victor would be clear of takeoff as soon as he was ready.
~z~I didn't know when their plane was scheduled to depart, but they wouldn't be waiting around.
~z~Rich people don't wait in airports like the rest of us. I'd have to hurry if I wanted to make takeoff.
~z~Victor Branco had the money, the connections, and the motivation to get out of Brazil quick.
~z~I'd be lucky if I got there as he reached cruising altitude.
~z~I could unpack some cases, and sniff panties to my heart's content,
~z~or I could get out there and follow through with the plan.
~z~There was only one passenger left on the platform. It was time to head to the next terminal.
~z~Nothing was happening back here. I had to get to where the action was.
~z~This wasn't the kind of place where you waited to board a private jet.
~z~Victor and Becker were out in the departure lounge somewhere.
~z~The baggage conveyor would get me onto the gang way.
~z~The departure gates were somewhere through that door.
~z~There was a power button on the console. Asshole.
~z~A gate had opened at the other end of the departure lounge.
~z~They weren't here. I had to keep moving down through the airport.
~z~Maybe they were in the next terminal. I'd keep looking until Victor sent me a postcard from Miami.
~z~There were some stairs that would take me up there.
~z~This was the back office. There'd be a way to the nearby lounge.
~z~It worked. The trams were running again. Maybe they'd take me to my gate.
~z~Maybe they'd bring more guys wanting to whack me. Maybe both.
~z~I couldn't turn my back on the other tram. There was a guy on board, and one guy was enough to kill me.
~z~It was perfect. Everyone wanted a ticket for the Max Payne express.
~z~Judgment with a smile, you can't beat it.
~z~How'd you get those things past the TSA?
~z~I rather not be blown up today.
~z~It didn't work out like that. Of course there'd a tram full of goons trying to derail me.
~z~There were UFE guys everywhere. But no immediate signs of Becker or Branco.
~z~I'd have to move down the gates, keep looking. Hell, maybe if I made some noise,
~z~they'd come out of a cologne shop.
~z~If I wasn't planning on packing myself in their suitcase, I'd have to go out into the main terminal.
~z~It looked like the way through was on the next level.
~z~Still no signs of Becker or Branco. I had to keep moving down the gates.
~z~Hell, maybe if I made some more noise, they'd come out of a cologne store.
~z~It looked like they were closing up shop.
~z~They'd cut the juice. I guess they didn't want anyone using the station.
~z~It had taken me right into the heart of it. Becker's gimps were everywhere.
~z~So he and Branco must be close. The smart move would have been sticking with Da Silva and going straight to the hangar.
~z~But when had I been about smart moves? I'm a dumb move guy?
~z~"Hey, Max we'll drive onto the runway." "No, thanks. Let me walk in the main entrance.
~z~I'll put a big shit-eating grin on my face, and let these assholes take turns trying to kill me."
~z~That's my style, and it's too late in the day to hope for to change.
~z~Boy, were they throwing numbers at this problem. But, then, I'd chosen to be here. I wanted this.
~z~Was it redemption? Not really. It was pathetic desperation, and not much else.
~z~So, of course I knew they were looking for me.
~z~But the airport was about the only place a fat gringo might blend in. Well, there or a sex club.
~z~My delusions of disguise lasted around two seconds.
~z~Either I'm more recognizable than I would hope. Or maybe they would have gone for any
~z~American in the midst of a mid life crisis who'd staggered through those doors.
~z~They were out in force, and they were out for me. But, then, I was out for them too.
~z~So, of course I knew they were looking for me.
~z~But the airport was about the only place a fat gringo might blend in.
~z~My delusions of disguise lasted around two seconds. They were out in force,
~z~and they were out for me. But, then, I was out for them too.
~z~I'd raised the curtain on another shoddy production of "try to kill the asshole".
~z~There were still some guys on the other tram hoping to get off a shot.
~z~And we were off. I felt like I might be able to recharge for a second.
~z~At least until we pulled into the station, and met more murderous assholes.
~z~The tram was slowing down. And I'd only just got on board.
~z~I had to salvage what I could, and see what was waiting for me.
~z~We were slowing down. And I'd only just got the tram to myself.
~z~Ah, I hoped I'd be going in the right direction.
~z~E uma emergencia! Vamos! Vai, vai, vai, vai, vai, porra!
~z~Ai, caralho. Outro gringo maluco. Porra, nao me mata nao, mata nao.
~z~Ai meu Deus! O que e que ta acontecendo?
~z~Ai! Nao tou gostando dessa porra nao, hein!
~z~Vamos, vamos! Todo mundo pra fora! Todo mundo pra fora!
~z~Vai, vai, vai, vai, vai, vai, vai... vai... VAI!
~z~Vamos! Vamos saindo daqui! Vamos! Vamos logo!
~z~Caralho! Esse filho da puta e louco, mano!
~z~You're pissing in the wrong pool, Mr. Payne.
~z~What do you expect to achieve here, Mr. Payne?
~z~Look what you've become, Mr. Payne. Another fucking terrorist.
~z~You know Max, you're just another gringo trying to impose his will on our world.
~z~You're pissing in another man's pool, Max.
~z~No one is paying you to be here, Max. Seu Merda!
~z~I ain't got nowhere else to go, Becker.
~z~I just wanna do my job, brother.
~z~You think Victor's gonna wait for you?
~z~You ain't gonna walk away from all these dead bodies, pal.
~z~How many more of your clowns you gonna send to their deaths?
~z~I'm going to get you, you dumb yankee.
~z~You trying to kill him or me?
~z~Are you trying to shake me off?
~z~Your career's coming down with that plane. Let's get it over with.
~z~The further in I got, the more guys I saw. Becker wasn't running a police force, he was running an army.
~z~These guys were better trained, and better equipped than anyone I'd seen out here,
~z~and I'd seen some mean sons of bitches.
~z~The mission was screaming suicide, but I didn't give a damn. At least I'd die being a pain in the ass.
~z~I'm going to stay here until I know it's clear.
~z~Short of riding in there on a parade float, we couldn't have made our arrival more obvious.
~z~We had to hide someplace out of the open.
~z~I had to get this poor girl out of there.
~z~Locked. And there was still the small matter of the traumatized girl sobbing behind the trash can.
~z~Ninguem sabia que ele seria um problema tao grande.
~z~Eu disse que deveriamos te-lo matado no estadio.
~z~O que estamos fazendo aqui? Isso e perda de tempo.
~z~Cale a boca e faca seu trabalho. Nao vamos sair daqui enquanto nao vasculharmos o lugar inteiro.
~z~...I wonder if Bravo Team found anything out here?
~z~Eu nao consigo falar com eles no radio. Ta muito quieto aqui. Eu nao to gostando disso nao, porra!
~z~I don't like it, not one bit.
~z~Ai o americano babaca querendo bancar o heroi aqui. Ele matou o Milo Rego. Nos queremos ele vivo ou morto!
~z~We can take him dead or alive.
~z~Grande bosta! E' mais um ratinho de merda!
~z~Me disseram que ele e' um louco do caralho...drogado! O cara quer morrer!
~z~Max... talk to me. What's going on!?
~z~What are we going to do, Max?
~z~You have to get us out of here.
~z~They're going to kill us, aren't they?
~z~Make sure you stay out of sight.
~z~I think we can get out this way.
~z~Max! Look out! There's more of them!
~z~We've got to get out of here.
~z~Are there more of them? What's going on?
~z~What are you doing? Max, talk to me.
~z~You're freaking me out, Max! Say something!
~z~This isn't funny, Max! We have to go!
~z~Why are they doing this, Max? This is so fucked up.
~z~Oh my god, you're one of them!
~z~Are you trying to draw attention to us?
~z~I thought we were trying to hide?
~z~We have to get out of here, Max.
~z~Come on, we need to find Passos.
~z~There are still more of them down there, Max.
~z~I still hear them, Max. I don't think it's clear.
~z~What are you doing? They'll kill us both!
~z~Let's go. I want to get out of here.
~z~Come on, Max. Passos is never going to find us in here.
~z~This place is giving me the creeps.
~z~I can't look at these dead bodies any more.
~z~Temos que encontrar a menina e o Americano tambem.
~z~Procura por todo lado. Vao vasculhar tudo.
~z~Ok? Nao podem deixar pedra sobra pedra.
~z~I'm not going out there, Max. They'll kill us.
~z~We can't move. Not with those lunatics still up there.
~z~You have to do something. We're trapped here.
~z~What are we going to do, Max?
~z~I didn't blame Giovanna for being afraid...
~z~I just hoped she could forgive me after being dragged through hell.
~z~I don't think these guys are here for your baby shower.
~z~Wishful thinking. Maybe there was a security switch somewhere.
~z~She was Victor's political nemesis and, in all probability, Sao Paulo's next mayor.
~z~Even the Brancos couldn't afford that many votes.
~z~Day two of sobriety was going about as well as day one.
~z~I needed to get to my unhappy place.
~z~When it's you and a pregnant woman against an army of mercenaries, you take what you can get.
~z~It felt strange dealing with any of this without a lining of scotch on the stomach. This would have to do.
~z~MAX! Where the fuck are you going?
~z~There had to be an easier way out of there than the way I came in.
~z~My "send the pregnant girl on ahead" plan clearly wasn't working. We had to stick together.
~z~An army of paramilitaries, and only my face had made the front page.
~z~What if Passos arrived already? We've got to get out of this place.
~z~I can still hear people up there, Max.
~z~I don't think It's safe to move yet.
~z~Make sure there's no more of them.
~z~I'm going to wait here. It's not safe.
~z~Is there a way to open these doors?
~z~It's locked. What are we going to do?
~z~I didn't have the code. I had to find another way to open this door.
~z~Just stay there. It's gonna be ok.
~z~There must be a button to lower the staircase...
~z~Thank god! I thought you'd never make it.
~z~Just keep your foot on the gas!
~z~What do you think I'm trying to do!?!
~z~What do you think I'm trying to do?
~z~Oh my god. What the hell is he doing?
~z~Just keep your foot on the gas.
~z~We're gonna be ok. You're doing great.
~z~Vai la! Vai la! Nao deixa eles fugir, porra!
~z~Esse filho da puta vai pagar ou nao vai, hein?!
~z~We have to get out of here!
~z~There must be a way to drop those stairs down.
~z~Wait a second... I'm going to try something.

~z~places where yuppies could gawk at the endless spirit of the poor from the inside of their bulletproof buses.
~z~I felt dumb and exposed. I missed the booze. Not that it mattered - sober or drunk, I was hardly undercover.

~z~What do you need guys? What do you need?

~z~O que e que voce ta fazendo aqui? Eu tou te perguntando. Eu te chamei aqui, porra!
~z~All things considered, I was gonna have to look on this as a good outcome. I was deep in gang territory.
~z~These kids were raised hating clowns like me - middle income ass kickers who protected the rich by shooting kids like them.
~z~Ah! Entao, voce e um americano de merda.
~z~Me da so uma razao pra eu nao te matar, seu americano burro!
~z~Passa tudo o que voce tem, viado.
~z~Pega o dinheiro dele, pega o dinheiro dele!
~z~Valeu, mano. Bem-vindo a favela Nova Esperanca!
~z~Agora da o fora daqui, caralho! (Max's dialogue overlaps the last word.)
~z~Assim voce mata o veio, hein! Haha.
~z~Ta esquentando. Vai, vai. Vamos comecar. Vai, vai. Ta esquentando...
~z~Ta ai, mais gostosa do que nunca.
~z~O, sai de cima de mim, meu! O!
~z~In more ways than I can possibly explain.
~z~I know you, at the disco, with the gun. Yeah, you had hair back then and better clothes.
~z~Anders Detling from Steele, North Dakota. Why on earth are you here?
~z~Well, I'm looking for someone. What are you doing here?
~z~Oh, we-we came to help the cause. See, after I retired my wife... She said I had to do something.
~z~And we'll you know, I always loved kids, so I got involved in Angels of the Hill. Oh, It's a great cause and they're really great folk
~z~and we'll now we come down twice a year to help innoculate the children of the Favelas. Yeah, oh simply wonderful giving back.
~z~Whole family does it, like my little girl is coming in a couple of days.
~z~Ah, I was a cop for twenty five years and grant it Steele ain't no Sao Paulo but
~z~you know I seen things and people are the same everywhere... Good, bad, indifferent...
~z~Listen, have you heard anything about a woman, about twenty eight, rich. She was kidnapped. I heard she being held around here.
~z~Alright, you too. You look like you need it. I gotta get back at it. I-I'll say a prayer for ya.
~z~Desculpa. Ola. Fala ingles? I'm a little lost. Perdido. Onde estou?
~z~A gente nao e centro de infomacao turistica nao, gringo.
~z~Well, they weren't gonna help me and who could blame them?
~z~were less popular than the clap. If I was gonna find my way out of this mess, I was on my own.

~z~ I was a dumb American in a place where dumb Americans were less popular than the clap.
~z~If I was going to find myself out of this mess, I was on my own.
~z~Interesting haircut by the way, meant to tell you that.
~z~Wilson Da Silva. Very good to meet you.
~z~Although you'll forgive me if I promise never to employ you as my bodyguard.
~z~You did a great job watching after Rodrigo Branco.
~z~Have you ever seen this guy? Serrano.
~z~Yeah, you sure put his gang out of business, but don't worry, those guys... they're small fry.
~z~This is the guy I'm interested in, Neves. And this is his little buddy here, Milo Rego.
~z~They work for this vigilante group, Cracha Preto.
~z~Well, they're very popular with right-wing politicians, like Victor Branco.
~z~Now you see many years ago, he helped clear some villages on a bit of land Rodrigo Branco wanted to develop.
~z~Yes. He did some very bad things. Anyway, have you ever seen this guy?
~z~I knew you were involved in that business, you know.
~z~I wanted to investigate that, but I got an order to blame it on some local street kids instead.
~z~Nothing. We... simply went to hand over some cash to this guy's clowns for a...
~z~a ransom exchange, when this guy's clowns jumped us and they shot everybody.
~z~Apart from you and your boy, Passos.
~z~That's right, but we had to shoot our way out of there.
~z~It's okay, it's a little weird right now, but I know that Victor Branco is involved in all this,
~z~I just don't know how or why.
~z~And I know that the UFE are involved in all this as well, but I just don't know how or why.
~z~And you know what's gonna happen? The moment is gonna come along when I put all these pieces together and at
~z~that moment, someone is gonna come along and put a bullet in my head.
~z~Anyway listen... think you might want this.

~z~So, why don't you just go get her?
~z~I don't know. I'm a cop, I mean I'll fight corruption.
~z~I'll stand up to the rich and dumb, but if I go up that hill right now... I'll be dead in three minutes or less.
~z~Maybe you too Max, you're in the jungle now.
~z~If you survive the next hour, let's speak. You help me, and I'm gonna do what I can to help you. Good luck.

~z~what was true and what was just someone else's convenient bullshit.

~z~E ai gringo, o que voce ta fazendo ai?

~z~I got a gun and if anybody thinks they're gonna take it from me they'd be dead wrong.

~z~Telefone? Vai, la no fundo, o. Segue em frente.
~z~When you're stuck in a foreign country and you don't know the words for reverse charges,
~z~and you're in some lonely skin joint in the middle of some poor slum having just had every last cent robbed from you,
~z~and you call yourself a body guard, then you know you're a loser.
~z~Hey Max. Can I buy you a beer?
~z~Look, if you're gonna shoot me, can you make it quick? I'm a little busy.

~z~Trying to dry out a bit so just a soda please.
~z~Sure. Why don't you go sit down?
~z~Um guarana pra ele e um chopp pra mim, bem gelado.
~z~I couldn't find any clues in this place so I decided to do my bit for the drugs trade.
~z~I was definitely in Comando Sombra territory. If Fabiana was still alive, she couldn't be far away.
~z~As I approached the spot I could hear raised voices.
~z~When I saw that Marcelo had turned up with a suitcase full of money along with Fabiana's sister,
~z~Giovanna. I only understood a little, but things were not going well.
~z~I wasn't expecting quite so many armed goons, but there was no backing out now,
~z~I would just have to act harder than I felt.
~z~Let the girls go. No-one needs to die, asshole.

~z~Va tomar no cu, seu gringo de merda! Vou matar todo...

~z~I had to hope the king was in his castle.
~z~Ah, geez buddy, am I glad to see you. Oh, fuck me...
~z~I've been coming to this shit hole town for the last five years. It's like a fucking insane asylum,
~z~but it's got the cheapest pussy in the world. Well, fuck me... I mean...
~z~You're in a cat house in the slums pal doing who knows what.
~z~I'm a business man bro, an-and they were fully legal. In-in this country I-I thin-think?
~z~And-and I know how to tip alright. It ain't my fault man. It ain't my fault. Don-Don't judge me alright.
~z~The fireworks display was clearly in my honor,
~z~making sure everyone knew to roll out the red carpet for their surprise guest.
~z~Esse ai, esse ai ja era, nao vale a pena nao.
~z~I thought I'd found Fabiana but instead I'd stumbled across some testosterone fest,
~z~a bunch of young punks with guns killing time the only way they knew how.
~z~Nova Esperanca wasn't exactly a dinner and movie kind of place. I recognized the hoods who jumped me earlier.
~z~I was trying to decide whether to crash this party or turn back,
~z~when my natural grace and finesse made the decision for me.
~z~Essa porra me da vontade de mijar! Vou la no banheiro.
~z~These bastards looked different: tougher, more capable.
~z~They didn't look like Serrano's boys, but I could tell I was moving up the food chain.
~z~I hoped Fabiana wasn't gonna be served up come feeding time.
~z~That much security, it had to be Serrano's pad.

~z~Vou queimar teu cu, filho da puta!

~z~Look, we really need to get out of New Jersey.

~z~Only difference now is, I didn't understand the language.
~z~Haven't you figured out I don't speak your fucking language?
~z~That's right, I may be a moron, but here's the thing...
~z~I ain't quite as dumb as I seem.
~z~It was time to get out of here.

~z~CHAPTER XII - THE GREAT AMERICAN SAVIOR OF THE POOR
~z~UFE... That deal at the favela was getting dirtier by the minute.
~z~Those bastards were clearly in bed with the Cracha Preto, now I just had to find out why.
~z~Starting with a bit of bedtime reading for Mr. Da Silva.
~z~I had to get those poor bastards out of there.
~z~Get 'em out of here. Go. Go! Both of you, quick! I said get... Serrano?
~z~Serrano, he looked pathetic, a man defeated. I walked away and left him to his own personal nightmare.
~z~Whatever hell this was Da Silva had sent me into, I knew I had to put an end to it.
~z~I had no choice but to push on. I didn't understand everything and I never would, but I understood enough.
~z~When you've lived the kinda life I've lived, reality comes at you through a different lens,
~z~but nothing could've prepared me for what was on the other side of that door.
~z~Sometimes a complicated problem is best tackled with a simple solution.
~z~What the fuck is going on here?!
~z~I am a doctor. I help people.

~z~Who wants to take a shot? You see what this is? Come on,

~z~You bodyguard for the Brancos, they are all dead. You help the poor, today, many of them dead.

~z~It's my new life, just like you said.

~z~Apart from the weight. Very funny... Ha ha... Yes, that is a fake laugh, you jerk.
~z~So here we were - miles up the Tiete River, looking for what? We did not know.
~z~Max. You listening? Max! So, like I was saying... I think they're a group called the Cracha Preto.
~z~So why'd you tell me they're called the "CS"?
~z~They are. I mean... Fabiana... she was kidnapped by the CS.
~z~But the guys that crashed our little party at the stadium, they were a group of paramilitaries.
~z~You'll have to forgive me for not being able to follow all this.
~z~You're not supposed to follow it. The government can't even follow it. It ensures that no one is ever guilty
~z~So why'd they do it - bust us at the stadium?
~z~Ahh, somebody told them we were going to be there with a whole lot of money.
~z~Anyway... the money's gone. I just hope we can get the girl back.
~z~Yeah, me too. I wonder where the hell she is.
~z~I know there's a harbor about a half a mile up. She's got to be there. This is a known Comando Sombra area.
~z~You know, if I'd be doing my job properly...
~z~we wouldn't be out here in the middle of nowhere looking for some broad who got pinched on my watch.
~z~That's what we tell ourselves. It's all our fault.
~z~No, I'm serious. By the time they grabbed the girls I was half cut. I ain't slippin' man - I'm slipped.
~z~Max, we work private security. We're all ex-soldiers, ex-special forces, ex-cops, ex-good guys.
~z~We all have our reasons why we became "ex". Maybe now we can put things right, okay?
~z~Yeah, I can see why you don't want to leave this place, Max. It's real charming.
~z~So look, I got some friends in Queens. We can stay there for a few days.
~z~CHAPTER V - ALIVE IF NOT EXACTLY WELL
~z~So that was it, was it? Say the magic word and be absolved of your sins? If only shit were that simple,
~z~I'd have done it years ago. Me? I'd been stuck in the past so long I'd forgotten what year it was.
~z~Hey, Max. Hey, quit your daydreaming - this is it. It's over there. I'm gonna cut the engine and glide in.
~z~You know, if I'd be doing my job properly...
~z~we wouldn't be out here in the middle of nowhere looking for some broad who got pinched on my watch.
~z~That's what we tell ourselves. It's all our fault.
~z~No, I'm serious. By the time they grabbed the girls I was half cut. I ain't slippin' man - I'm slipped.
~z~Max, we work private security. We're all ex-soldiers, ex-special forces, ex-cops, ex-good guys.
~z~We all have our reasons why we became "ex". Maybe now we can put things right, okay?
~z~Por que e que eu sempre fico com a parte de merda? Porra!
~z~I couldn't understand them, but I didn't have to. Cheap hoods are the same from here to Timbuktu.
~z~The slab of meat on the boat was clearly the boss. Serrano, they called him.
~z~And it seemed that our suspicions were correct. Fabiana was here, somewhere further ahead.
~z~I had to find her quickly and quietly, if possible. Last thing I wanted was a party with these clowns.
~z~Ja te falei pra tu parar de reclamar e fazer o teu trabalho, mano...
~z~Max? Max! Are you alright? What's going on? Where's Fabiana?
~z~They took her in a boat! That way. Straight ahead.
~z~Things were falling apart...again. The CS were getting real jumpy and Fabiana's safety was in jeopardy.
~z~That was the chopper the Comando Sombra used to escape the nightclub attack.
~z~If Fabiana wasn't around here, then at least someone that knew where she was had to be.
~z~It looked like Passos had brought us to the right place.
~z~I'd seen enough to know that Fabiana was at least alive, if not exactly well.
~z~Her captors didn't look like they were quite the kind and gentle type. I had to find that room quickly.
~z~O, da um cigarro ai. Eu nao tenho, porra.
~z~Oi, Dani, voce ta ai? Voce tem um cigarro?
~z~O, da um cigarro ai. Eu nao tenho, porra.
~z~Esses caras nao chegam de jeito nenhum, viu.
~z~Vem ca, da um beijinho no papi.
~z~I had to keep moving. I hoped that I'd find Fabiana sooner than later... if at all.
~z~That was the chair that she had been held in. I had just missed them.
~z~Para de chorar, menina. Para de chorar, sua puta. Porra! Cala a boca, ninguem pode te ouvir, caralho.
~z~There she was - right in front of me.
~z~The drunk fool in me wanted to make a play...
~z~but I had just about enough sense to know that I'd end up with another dead girl in my arms if I did.
~z~Sua burguesinha safada. Vou te pegar, hein. Vou te pegar antes que eu bote uma bala na tua cabeca.
~z~Esse filho da puta ta vivo ainda!
~z~There they were! I had the feeling I'd been running one step behind ever since I got to this country...
~z~and maybe few years before that as well.
~z~We have reports of more violence erupting in Panama where citizens are still reeling from this attack 2 months ago.
~z~Colombian paramilitary group United Souls of the People or AUP have been waging a campaign of violence and
~z~despite government attempts to stabilize the region, Staying in Latin America, ,
~z~an explosion of violence in Brazil's largest city Sao Paulo
~z~as much publicized initiatives to stop feuding between favela gangs and the police have completely failed.
~z~Some local activists blame much of the cities problems on the activities of right-wing groups Cracha Preto and Nova Guarda,
~z~who they accuse of vigilante style attacks in areas of the city where police have lost control.
~z~Some Human Rights Organizations report a slew of missing persons in the city,
~z~a topic that many observers say local law enforcement isn't taking seriously.
~z~This turmoil is shaping up to be hot topic in next year's mayoral election.
~z~Right wing candidate Victor Branco, was once a front runner but is now falling behind in the polls.
~z~Well, There may be some political storm clouds out there but the sun is shining in many regions today.
~z~I'd been sitting at the bar for about three hours or about five years, depending on how you looked at things.
~z~I tried not to look at things.
~z~I tried not to think about when it was that my existence became less about the things that make up people's
~z~lives, and more about the holes that losing those things leave behind,
~z~but I wasn't doing a very good job at it.
~z~These pricks had been annoying me for days. They were typical Jersey rich kids.
~z~The ring leader, I think his name was Tony. His dad was some well known hood. Drug dealer. Racketeer.
~z~Hey, let me ask you a question, where the fuck are your donuts?
~z~This kid had a well developed sense of humor, for New Jersey.
~z~At least we know where she is.
~z~Sure, trouble finds us the same way you found me, slumped in a bar, drunk on self-pity.
~z~CHAPTER IV - ANYBODY CAN BUY ME A DRINK
~z~Seriously, I thought I told you to get out of here, old man.
~z~That's a nice echo. Do gorillas have personalities of their own, or do they just agree with everything you say?
~z~Very funny old man. Very fucking funny.
~z~Yeah, has been washed up old cop. Should go on TV.
~z~Tell some jokes about how you got your wife killed, or some shit.
~z~Or how you got involved with killers. I own this town, amigo.
~z~That's a good line. Do you practice that in front of the mirror in your underwear? Your father owns this town.
~z~Yeah, dear old Dad... well known drug dealer and murderer. You're nothing but a chump.
~z~Hey, don't you disrespect my family. You ain't got the right.
~z~Hey, don't take that from this punk, Tone.
~z~I ain't taking nothing from him god hasn't already deprived him of...
~z~But, I might start, any time! Now say you're sorry, fucking has been cop, mother fucker! Say you are sorry!
~z~And look away from me. Look away from me. Don't you stare at me. Say you're sorry.
~z~Don't act clever, you fucking leather jacket dip shit cop cunt. Don't act clever.
~z~I will blow your brains all over this counter. Every fucking where.
~z~Yeah... Don't fuck with me, Marty. I'll shoot you as well. Don't fuck with me
~z~Put the gun down. Now. Thank you, thank you. Now get the fuck out of here, before one of you gets shot.
~z~Who the fuck are you? You spic fuck.
~z~We're coming back for you, you fuck.
~z~Stay right here, stay right here. You don't know who you're fucking with.
~z~Max fucking Payne. How you doing man?
~z~I'm doing about as good as I look...
~z~You don't remember me? Passos... Raul Passos? Come on we went to the academy together man... You don't remember?
~z~That's going back a long way friend.
~z~I spent five years on the beat in the Bronx. Working homicide. Nearly got killed man.
~z~I gave up... I got into private work. Here, Central America, Brazil where my family comes from... all over.
~z~Ah... That's great. Travel, see the world.
~z~Yeah keeps me busy. I take care of people you know, proper body guarding. Hey, I'm working for a good firm.
~z~I'm actually here on a bit of a recruitment drive.
~z~Yeah... Well, why don't you drive on off back into the sunset there Pessos. It's been nice catching up.
~z~At least let me buy you a drink?
~z~Yeah, sure. Anybody can buy me a drink.
~z~Look, this is the way we do it in Brazil baby!
~z~I had to admit, I kind of liked the guy.
~z~He had a great set of stories., but I still wasn't interested in becoming a white knight again.
~z~What, I don't look like I go to Shakespeare or something?
~z~You faggots still got something to say to me?
~z~I don't like spics who tell me to fuck off.
~z~Well, good for you. Now fuck off.
~z~You heard me. I'm not frightened of you, you spray tan guido douche.
~z~Girl sure had balls, I had to give her that.
~z~I don't know why I did it. Guess I never liked seeing girls get hit.
~z~But from the moment, I was dead in that town.
~z~You don't know who you're fucking with
~z~C'mon. Hey, another round, another round, Max is buying.
~z~I don't know why I did it. I guess I never liked seeing girls getting hit, but from that moment I was dead in that town.
~z~Yeah, I'm good. I live right around the corner, let's go this way.
~z~The bar was right around the corner from my apartment. It only took a few minutes to get back.
~z~They ain't gonna make this easy for us are they?
~z~I got an idea. Hold them here.
~z~He coulda been setting me up for a fall, but something told me to stay put and trust him.

~z~Shhhh! Shhhh my boy. Don't be afraid of the fires. You think they'll hurt ya.

~z~Why don't you step it up over there.

~z~Get out of here, it's the cops!

~z~Should be a bit quieter in here.
~z~Yeah I can see why you don't want to leave this place, Max. It's real charming.

~z~Hey Max, what is it with you and interior design, huh?
~z~You...you really know how to give a place a great lived in feel, huh. This is beautiful.
~z~Fuck off with the fuckin' wise cracks. Really, I'm not in the mood.
~z~Okay. Sorry bro. The boss wants to see us, so let's go. Come on.
~z~Take your time man. Fucking unbelievable. Jesus.
~z~I don't think we ever had much of a chance. No one told us they had an entire goddamn army.
~z~I don't think anybody knew. This is some crazy shit.
~z~Yeah, it's all crazy, pal. Non-stop insanity. I thought I left all of this shit behind. Easy gig, you said.
~z~What a fool I was to get involved in this madness.
~z~Ohh, give me a second, I'm not feeling so good.
~z~CHAPTER VI A DAME, A DORK, AND A DRUNK
~z~I'm sorry sir, we risked our lives several times over trying to save her.
~z~I-I-I-I... I know. I just wish I knew what was happening and why.
~z~Yes, who has it in for our family?
~z~I mean just because we are rich and happy.
~z~Is that a good reason to hate us? I do a lot of good in this town - a lot!
~z~As I told you yesterday, when I get Fabiana back I think I will move us to Miami or Geneva.
~z~I... It feels like nothing good can come from living in Sao Paulo right now.
~z~I hope you're not giving up on our city Senhor Branco. Listen, we will catch the men.
~z~Yes, these are tough times, but we have been through it before, like when father died.
~z~Father had a heart attack visiting a brothel.
~z~Yeah, it was humiliating and embarrassing for sure... but now this is different. This is the end for me.
~z~Well she's not dead. Maybe we'll be lucky and get her back safe soon.
~z~I can almost guarantee it. If you do as I ask.
~z~I know this has been tough on you, but things will get better... for all of us.
~z~Marcelo, Passos, in my helicopter - this way.
~z~Ate logo, Sr. Branco, and may I say,
~z~you would be best served se contratar profissionais e nao esses amadores pes-de-chinelo.
~z~Sometimes it feels like I have done nothing apart from being a rich man, in a poor country.
~z~The men I talk to, they only see money. Now my wife... I am not naive. She does not love me for my body.
~z~Well, despite your good fortune you're still a decent man.
~z~Am I? I don't know. I try to be. But maybe I'm just another rich fool, just like the rest of my friends.
~z~Com licenca. Tem uma ligacao pro senhor, um policial chamado Sr. Da Silva.
~z~Fala pra ele me ligar de volta.
~z~O que que o senhor acha? Claro que sim. E o senhor bem pontual, hein?
~z~Another bent cop wanting a pension contribution.
~z~Do you think a pile of shit feels popular because it's surrounded by flies? Look at me, I'm a mess.
~z~Senhor, temos um problema. O sistema de seguranca foi desativado.
~z~I can see that! We've got men entering the building and the office won't lock down.
~z~Let us give you a ride, no?
~z~It's not working. Uhh... there's a way to reboot the system.
~z~If I can get to the server room I should be able to get everything back online.
~z~Strange. You pay a couple of million dollars and you expect to... to push a button to...
~z~to be able to make all your problems go away. All I got was some useless junk and a bit of false confidence.
~z~Sir, let us handle this. Stay in your office. Lock yourself in.
~z~Do not answer the door unless you know it's me. Let's go.
~z~I should be able to override the system if I can just get to the server room.
~z~Nothing to worry about, everything is fine. Get down behind the desk now, both of you.
~z~Ah. Diga que eu ligo mais tarde.
~z~Your guy's working on the security system now, sir.
~z~Okay, good. Then lock down yourself down. Stay put. Let us take care of these guys down here.
~z~Once they realize they can't get to you they should back off.
~z~Max, try not to completely destroy the place?
~z~Let's just concentrate on staying alive. Sir.
~z~Come on, move! Are you gonna be able to fix this or what?
~z~Give me a few minutes. eh. I should be able to reboot the system - get all the components back online.
~z~What about Branco's office? That's all I care about.
~z~He should be able to lock us down eh, if this works.
~z~Alright, well whatever you're doing, do it quick.
~z~I'm gonna make a sweep of the building and then get back to Rodrigo's.
~z~The security system was back online. Things might be a little tougher for our fan club from here on in.
~z~Seemed like breaching the perimeter had been no more difficult than strolling through the front gates.
~z~But hey, who needs a Trojan horse when the alarm is down and your standing army is a dame, a dork and a... drunk?
~z~Poor girl was dead. Shot through the head by some hero fighting the rich, one lonely secretary at a time.
~z~Pega esse... mata esse gringo filho da puta!
~z~I didn't know what the hell I was gonna find up there,
~z~but I sensed it wasn't gonna be a stripper bursting out of a cake.
~z~Senhor Branco! Senhor Branco! I can't get through to him - ever since the security doors triggered he hasn't made a sound.
~z~Rodrigo, it's Max. Open up. Can you hear me?
~z~I'm gonna try to get in there from the roof. You find the security guard and get the hell out of here.
~z~I knew there was another way in upstairs for the helipad.
~z~The little luxury run around that kept the rich looking down on the poor literally as well as metaphorically.
~z~Of course he was dead. Clean. One shot. A professional job. I began to look for clues.
~z~I had a liver like a French goose and skin like red leather.
~z~It was the only hope I had.
~z~but he'd been fair to me, and I let him down.
~z~Glad to see the security system is keeping the right people out.
~z~Sure, he'd been born with all the money and opportunity in the world...
~z~But then why had everyone else come driving through the goddamn wall?
~z~Someone in this building was trying to keep things low-key.
~z~at least my mid-life crisis would confuse them enough so they did something stupid.
~z~I could see that now. I decided that I was gonna die sober, not drunk. At least then I would see who shot me.
~z~Mind if I take a quick statement?
~z~They could have tried harder to sell us on a suicide but,
~z~I couldn't get playback on one of the cameras and it looked like the disc was missing.
~z~At least I was... facing in the right direction.
~z~It was time to take back control from whoever was out to get me.
~z~I was a mess. Rodrigo Branco was dead. Fabiana was held hostage. I had no idea who was behind any of this.
~z~Well, it wasn't perfect. In fact, it wasn't much good at all, but it was gonna have to do.
~z~I felt like a fool. I was a sweaty, gray-haired mess. This place... well, this place was gonna kill me too.
~z~If the gun had been fired it would have felt hot and smelled of powder.
~z~I knew I wasn't thinking straight - I'd been drinking and popping painkillers for years.
~z~I guess forensics don't much matter in a town where judges are bought, and juries are intimidated.
~z~This code should get us into the boardroom. Okay.
~z~Yeah, it's safe. Come on. We need to get you to the server room, let's go.
~z~Por que nao posso ficar aqui com voce debaixo da mesa?
~z~The server room is just past those cubicles.
~z~These clowns were the same guns for hire who'd jumped our exchange at the stadium.
~z~Cracha Preto - The Black Badge, right-wing paramilitary chumps protecting whoever paid the most.
~z~I guess that made them more like me than I... cared to admit.
~z~Were they just looking for another payday or did their business with the Brancos run deeper?
~z~O que que eu lhe falei? O que que eu lhe falei?
~z~A proxima pessoa que falar vai levar uma bala.
~z~Hey. We're good to go. Let's get that server back online.
~z~Can we just spend a few more minutes? Make sure they're all gone?
~z~Come on. Don't worry, I got your back.
~z~Poor kid was scared shitless, but I thought we'd seen the worst of it.
~z~Okay. Th-the server room is just down here.
~z~Eh? I just... I didn't think I'd have a day like this when I wake up in the mornings.
~z~Wish I could say the same thing.
~z~Fact was, I'd gotten used to protecting Branco in the big bad world.
~z~We hadn't anticipated a siege situation here. Hadn't prepared for it. I couldn't tell the kid that.
~z~Something told me these guys didn't have security clearance.
~z~Panama had been my second job with Passos.
~z~The first had been easy, money for banging waitresses at some fancy wedding in the Caribbean.
~z~It was the middle of the day and like any self-respecting idiot, I was half-cut.
~z~Ooh! Nossa, nothing like doing some good blow with some good friends on a boat.
~z~Daphne! Come here, I love this one.
~z~Oh Marcelo, you're going to be the death of me. Alfredo, more shots!
~z~This sure beats New Jersey, huh Max?
~z~Well... Everybody's drunk and tanned and listening to house music.
~z~Most of them have plastic surgery and they're all doing blow. I guess it is kinda like Jersey, huh.
~z~That's very funny Max, hey. Hey, saude!
~z~I've got to quit drinking so much. I'll give myself serious liver damage.
~z~Hey, big deal. You can always get a new one. Relax!
~z~I hope you're not drinking on the job gentlemen? Ha-ha,
~z~just kidding I hope you are! Just stay off the yayo hmm? I don't have enough to share.
~z~I'm kidding again! Aw, Mikey, even though we just met I feel like we are good friends you know? I feel like,
~z~safe with you guys. Know that? Like real safe.
~z~Yeah, and I love New York, err... the East Hamptons - do you know it?
~z~Uh, not really. I'd - I spent my honeymoon in... Montauk.
~z~Okay, whatever. Last time I was there I got so wasted I nearly shit myself. I didn't know you were married.
~z~Ah, good... Not good. Bad. Real bad.
~z~But good because now, I can get you laid... a lot! It is great to be single, eh. I love a woman.
~z~She's with another and she doesn't want to know it. Fuck her. I mean, could you believe that shit?
~z~Excuse me, I'm going to uhh... go to speak to Philippe.
~z~Philippe! You crazy crack head, lay off the yayo eh? Passos, walk with me.
~z~What's the deal with this guy eh? He's kind of... stuck up.
~z~But have him smile a bit more you know? Because life, life is good! Where's the truck?
~z~Hey Passos, I gotta go and lay down.
~z~I didn't know what to say. I had been so loaded in Panama, I could scarcely remember my own name. I know things had got real heavy.
~z~CHAPTER XI - SUN TAN OIL, STALE MARGARITAS AND GREED
~z~5:18PM, TUESDAY, A COUPLE OF MONTHS AGO
~z~If I'd known back then that they'd been up to no good while I was fighting my way through a band of violent
~z~paramilitaries, and a worse hangover, I might not have wanted to get over to them so bad.
~z~Ah, nothing... We're just, ehh...getting a few things out of here.
~z~I'll see you boys later. You take care of business here eh?
~z~Err... Do whatever you think is best.
~z~I think it's best we try to go find her.

~z~I didn't realize you knew your way around here.
~z~They were using that building to get across the canal.
~z~Come on! If we're gonna get her, let's get her!

~z~The epidemic of violence that grips Brazil's major cities continues to worsen.

~z~This is INC... a star midfielder for one of Sao Paulo's most famous clubs, Galatians, was killed in a bloody shootout at a local nightclub.
~z~A witness who captured this video said there was a fight between gang members and private security forces.
~z~It is not yet known whether this was a targeted hit or if the football star was simply in the wrong place at the wrong time.
~z~Also in the attack, Fabiana Branco, the young wife of a prominent local businessman, Rodrigo Branco, was kidnapped.
~z~Mr. Branco's brother, Victor, currently serves as a Federal Deputy in Sao Paulo, and is planning to run for mayor in next year's municipal elections.
~z~A new report by a team of sociologists from the US says the widening wealth gap is leading to a host of unforeseen social
~z~and psychological issues for people on both sides of the divide - including both an increase in crime and greater fear of crime,
~z~and rise in depression, drugs and alcohol abuse across all socioeconomic groups.
